page.title: Nominal Phrases - Noun Compounds, Complements and Gerunds
page.introduction:
Many languages are like English, in that they have noun modifiers. Normally, we simply think that all nouns can also be used as adjectives, but a closer look reveals that true adjectives come before the noun modifier, as in large, round [syrup bottle] but not *round, syrup large bottle. Therefore, we will treat noun modifiers as compound nouns which are written as separate words.
In the English examples above, bottle is clearly the head noun rather than syrup, because syrup is restricting the type of bottle, not the other way around. In all compound nouns and noun modifier constructions in English, the head is the right-most noun in the series.

form.introduction:
Now consider prepositional or postpositional phrase (PP) modifiers (or complements), such as in the large, round bottle [of syrup] and the boy’s letter [to that girl].
Think also of examples of genitive prepositional or postpositional phrases that take the place of the possessor, such as those dogs [of his] and the tablecloth [of my mother’s].

form.introduction: Another case which may look like a noun and a complement may actually be a gerund or gerund phrase. This whole phrase occupies a normal argument position, such as subject, object, indirect object or the object of a preposition. Some English examples in full sentences with the gerund phrase bracketed include:

EnglishExample.exItem: The receiver showed his worth by [making the catch].

form.introduction: Such phrases may be possessed or be modified as well, and sometimes only the gerund stands alone as the head of a nominal phrase, as in the badly wounded, the dying and your following. Therefore, we will allow gerund phrases to occupy the head position in the nominal phrase.

Note that the head of these gerund phrases is categorically a verb, so these are derived nominals. They will remain verbs in our grammar rules, but need to be distinguished as gerunds so that only the gerund forms of verbs may be used as nouns. The appropriate features will be added in section
